text: Edit tables.R, plots.R, map.R washi default fonts colors organization’s. Modify functions better suit data reporting needs. need source modified R scripts producer_report.qmd document. avoid confusion, also rename modified function R script .qmd document. example, let’s modify make_texture_triangle() use different default fonts colors: Note Mac OS users: facetted plotly strip plots issues overlapping labels. default panel_spacing arguments make_plotly() optimized rendering reports Windows machine. plots don’t look right machine, try modifying panel_spacing arguments described function documentation.
code: # In `plots.R`  # `soils` default arguments: make_texture_triangle <- function(   df,   primary_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["red"]],   secondary_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["gray"]],   other_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["tan"]],   font_family = "Poppins"     )   ... }  # Edit to: make_texture_triangle_custom <- function(   df,   primary_color = "blue",   secondary_color = "green",   other_color = "gray",   font_family = "Arial"     )   ... }      # In `producer_report.qmd`  # Add this to your setup chunk source(here::here("R/plots.R"))  # Ctrl + F to find and replace all instances of `make_texture_triangle(...)` # to `make_texture_triangle_custom(...)`.

title: Write Soil Health Reports
text: also can render report programmatically: year producer ID incorporated file name. can specify output directory want reports stored. ’re ready render reports producers project, use render_report() function purrr::walk(). iterate producer ID year render reports :
code: # Get the first producer ID in 2023 first_producer <- exampleData |>   subset(year == 2023) |>   head(1)  # Render html to the `/inst/reports/` directory render_report(   first_producer$producerId,   year = 2023,   input = "producer_report.qmd",   output = "html",   output_dir = paste0(here::here(), "/inst/reports/") ) # Get all unique producer IDs in 2023 producers <- exampleData |>   subset(year == 2023) |>   dplyr::distinct(producerId)  # Render docx for these 2023 producers to the `/inst/reports/` directory purrr::walk(   producers$producerId,   \(producerId) render_report(     producerId,     year = 2023,     input = "producer_report.qmd",     output = "docx",     output_dir = paste0(here::here(), "/inst/reports/")   ),   .progress = TRUE )

what: Make facetted strip plot interactive with plotly — make_plotly
title: Make facetted strip plot interactive with plotly — make_plotly
text: Wrapper make_strip_plot() adds plotly interactivity. NOTE: plotly issues overlapping axis labels facetting (See GitHub issue). somewhat hacky solution getting plots look good involves tweaking panel_spacing arguments ggplot2::theme(). rendering Mac OS, try setting panel_spacing_x = 0.01 panel_spacing_y = 3.

title: Make facetted strip plot interactive with plotly — make_plotly
code: make_plotly(   df,   panel_spacing_x = 6,   panel_spacing_y = 30,   font_family = "Poppins",   primary_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["red"]],   secondary_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["ltgray"]],   other_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["tan"]],   primary_accent_color = washi::washi_pal[["standard"]][["blue"]] )

title: Make facetted strip plot interactive with plotly — make_plotly
text: df Dataframe containing columns: category, abbr_unit, unit, dummy, sampleLabel. panel_spacing_x, panel_spacing_y Spacing facet panels units line output = "html". Defaults 6 x 30 y rendering producer reports. default values seem look best dimensions plot outputs reports. argument used deal plotly issues. See make_plotly() examples. font_family Font family use throughout plot. Defaults "Poppins". primary_color Color producer's sample points Defaults WaSHI green. secondary_color Color sample points "crop" "county" values category column. Defaults WaSHI gray. other_color Color sample points "fields" value category column. Defaults WaSHI tan. primary_accent_color Color facet strip background. Defaults WaSHI blue.

code:
# Read in wrangled plot data # See `data_wrangling.R` for processing steps path <- soils_example("dfPlot.csv") df <- read.csv( path, encoding = "UTF-8" ) # The data structure necessary to render the df triangle dplyr::slice_sample( df, n = 1, by = category ) |> dplyr::glimpse() #> Rows: 4 #> Columns: 23 #> $ year 2022, 2023, 2023, 2023 #> $ dummy "dummy", "dummy", "dummy", "dummy" #> $ category "Other fields", "Same county", "Same crop", "You… #> $ sampleLabel "Result:", "County 9
Cereal Grain
Result:"… #> $ sampleId "22-EHJ01-01", "23-DJU01-03", "23-KVP07-01", "23… #> $ farmName "Farm 038", "Farm 148", "Farm 127", "Farm 150" #> $ producerName "Aileen", "Raashid", "Jessica", "Shanna" #> $ producerId "EHJ01", "DJU01", "KVP07", "WUY05" #> $ fieldName "Field 01", "Field 03", "Field 01", "Field 03" #> $ fieldId 1, 3, 1, 3 #> $ county "County 8", "County 9", "County 22", "County 9" #> $ crop "Vegetable", "Cereal Grain", "Hay/Silage", "Past… #> $ texture "Loamy Sand", "Loamy Sand", "Sandy Loam", "Sandy… #> $ longitude -123, -120, -120, -119 #> $ latitude 47, 48, 47, 49 #> $ measurement "WHC_in.ft", "bd_g.cm3", "sand_%", "sand_%" #> $ value 0.80, 1.27, 58.00, 64.00 #> $ measurement_group "physical", "physical", "physical", "physical" #> $ order 7, 5, 1, 1 #> $ measurement_full_name "Water Holding Capacity", "Bulk Density", "Sand"… #> $ abbr "WHC", "Bulk Density", "Sand", "Sand" #> $ unit "in/ft", "g/cm³", "%", "%" #> $ abbr_unit "WHC
(in/ft)", "Bulk Density
(g/cm³)", "… # Make sure class of `category` is `ordered factor` with `Your fields` at the # end so it is plotted on top of the other points df$category <- factor( df$category, levels = c( "Other fields", "Same county", "Same crop", "Your fields" ), ordered = TRUE ) class(df$category) #> [1] "ordered" "factor" levels(df$category) #> [1] "Other fields" "Same county" "Same crop" "Your fields" # Make the plot make_strip_plot( df, output = "static", font_family = "sans" )

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
text: ggplot2 texture triangle.

title: Make a texture triangle — make_texture_triangle
code: # Install and register Poppins font in R with the `{extrafont}` package. library(extrafont) #> Registering fonts with R  # Read in wrangled texture data # See `data_wrangling.R` for processing steps path <- soils_example("dfTexture.csv") df <- read.csv(path)  # Glimpse at data structure dplyr::slice_sample(   df,   n = 1,   by = category ) |>   dplyr::glimpse() #> Rows: 4 #> Columns: 7 #> $ sampleId <chr> "23-OLV08-01", "23-DJU01-03", "22-VTR04-02", "23-WUY05-03" #> $ category <chr> "Other fields", "Same county", "Same crop", "Your fields" #> $ Field    <chr> "Field 01", "Field 03", "Field 02", "Field 03" #> $ Texture  <chr> "Sandy Loam", "Loamy Sand", "Silt Loam", "Sandy Loam" #> $ Sand     <int> 68, 84, 12, 64 #> $ Silt     <int> 26, 10, 65, 33 #> $ Clay     <int> 6, 6, 23, 3  # Make sure class of `category` is `ordered factor` with `Your fields` at the # end so it is plotted on top of the other points df$category <- factor(   df$category,   levels = c(     "Other fields",     "Same county",     "Same crop",     "Your fields"   ),   ordered = TRUE )  class(df$category) #> [1] "ordered" "factor"   levels(df$category) #> [1] "Other fields" "Same county"  "Same crop"    "Your fields"   # Make the plot make_texture_triangle(   df,   font_family = "sans" ) #> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggtern': #>   method           from    #>   grid.draw.ggplot ggplot2 #>   plot.ggplot      ggplot2 #>   print.ggplot     ggplot2

title: Render reports — render_report
text: Wrapper quarto::quarto_render() additional project specific arguments. Limits output formats .html .docx. word document outputs opened manually edited ensure report looks good. See vignette("docx", package = "soils") details edits

title: Render reports — render_report
code: render_report(producerId, year, input, output = "html", output_dir = NULL)

title: Render reports — render_report
text: producerId Character producerId render report . year Year samples include report. input Input .qmd file name. Must within inst folder. output Target output format. Currently supported options: "html" interactive report. "docx" editable word document. output_dir Path directory holds reports. NULL, reports saved project directory.

title: Render reports — render_report
code: if (FALSE) { # Render single html report for first producer in data set first_producer <- head(exampleData$producerId, 1) render_report(   first_producer,   year = 2023,   input = "producer_report.qmd",   output = "html",   output_dir = paste0(here::here(), "/inst/reports/") )  producers <- exampleData |>   subset(year == 2023) |>   dplyr::distinct(producerId)  # Render docx for these 2023 producers to the `/inst/reports/` directory purrr::walk(   producers$producerId,   \(producerId) render_report(     producerId,     year = 2023,     input = "producer_report.qmd",     output = "docx",     output_dir = paste0(here::here(), "/inst/reports/")   ),   .progress = TRUE ) }

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
text: plot Plot save, defaults last plot displayed. path Path directory save plot . File name determined name plot file extension. device Device use. Can either device function (e.g. png), one "eps", "ps", "tex" (pictex), "pdf", "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "bmp", "svg" "wmf" (windows ). width, height, units Plot size units ("", "cm", "mm", "px"). supplied, uses size current graphics device.

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot

title: ggplot2::ggsave() with default arguments — save_plot
code: library(ggplot2)  plot <- exampleData |>   ggplot(aes(crop)) +   geom_bar() +   coord_flip()  # Create temp file to save plot file <- tempfile()  # Save plot save_plot(plot, path = file)  # Delete plot file unlink(file)
